content.text: Calculate the initial weight of the rocket
Define, in words, the term weight
A rocket has an initial mass of \(7.4 \times 10^{6} \text{kg}\)
Describe the motion of the rocket:
From O to A
From A to B
Draw a tangent to the graph at time \(= 400 \mathrm{s}\) and use this to calculate the acceleration of the rocket at this time. Show your working
acceleration =   .........
Fig. 1.1 shows part of the speed-time graph for the rocket as it leaves the ground and travels into space
Rockets are used to launch satellites into space. When the satellite is released, the rocket returns to the Earth
Explain in terms of forces why the rocket reaches terminal velocity as it travels through the atmosphere back to the Earth
Define momentum
Calculate the impulse on the golf ball
impulse =   .........
Calculate the force applied to the ball by the golf club

The golf club is in contact with the ball for \(5.0 \times 10^{- 4} \text{s}\). The velocity of the golf ball as it leaves the golf club is \(41 \text{m/s}\). The golf ball has a mass of \(0.046 \text{kg}\)
Fig. 2.1 shows a golfer about to hit a golf ball with a golf club. The initial momentum of the golf ball is zero
Fig. 2.1
State two energy resources for which radiation from the Sun is the main source of energy
Show that the mass of air hitting the turbine each second is approximately \(550 \text{kg}\)
Calculate the efficiency of the turbines. You may assume that all the kinetic energy stored in the wind is transferred to the turbine
efficiency =   .........  %
A wind turbine is used to generate electricity
The useful output from the turbine in 1.0 s is 6000 J. The kinetic energy of the wind hitting the turbine in 1.0 s is 11 000 J. The velocity of the wind hitting the turbine is \(6.3 \text{m / s}\)
Tidal energy and wind energy are both renewable energy resources
Suggest one reason why tidal energy is a more useful energy resource than wind energy
Ignore the costs of construction and maintenance
The pressure cooker is half-full of water. As the water is heated some water evaporates before the water boils
Describe **two** differences between evaporation and boiling of the water in the cooker
As the water is heated, the pressure of the gas inside the cooker increases
Explain this increase in pressure in terms of particles
Fig. 4.1 shows a pressure cooker on an electric heating element. The cooker has a tight-fitting lid
Explain why the surface temperature of the tarmac increases
State the method of thermal energy transfer from the tarmac to the air **immediately** above the road
State the main method of thermal energy transfer from the air immediately above the road to the rest of the air
Explain why the surface temperature of the tarmac is higher than the surrounding air temperature
On a sunny day, the temperatures of a black tarmac road and the air above the road increase
State the wave effect that allows the young teacher to hear sounds from the violin at the position he is standing in Fig. 6.1
Calculate the frequency of sound with a wavelength of \(0.75 \text{m}\)
The speed of sound in air is \(340 \text{m/s}\)
frequency =   .........
A violin produces sounds in the frequency range \(200 \text{Hz} - 3800 \text{Hz}\). The width of the open doorway is \(0.75 \text{m}\)
Explain why the young teacher hears the frequency calculated in **(a)(ii)** clearly but finds a frequency of \(3500 \text{Hz}\) much harder to hear
A plane mirror is placed at point X so that the teacher can see the student
On Fig. 6.1:
* draw a light ray from the violin to point X and from point X to the teacher
* draw and label the mirror
* add an arrow to the ray to show how the teacher sees the student
Use a ruler and sharp pencil for this drawing
A student plays the violin near the doorway to a large room. Fig. 6.1 shows a young teacher standing where he can hear the sound but cannot see the student
State the meaning of electromotive force
State the potential difference (p.d.) across the heater
Calculate the current in the heater
Current =
The current in the motor is 1.6A
Determine the reading on the ammeter in Fig. 7.1. Explain your answer
Ammeter reading
Explanation
A washing machine has an electric motor and an electric heater. Fig. 7.1 shows a simplified circuit diagram for the washing machine
The heater has a resistance of \(25\Omega\) and the power supply has an electromotive force (e.m.f.) of \(230\mathrm{V}\)
State the name of sound waves which have a frequency greater than \(20\mathrm{kHz}\)
High frequency sound waves travel from the boat through the sea water
The speed of sound in water is \(1500 \text{m/s}\). The seabed is \(22 \text{m}\) below the boat
Calculate the time taken for the boat to receive the reflected wave from the seabed after the sound is emitted
Fig. 8.2 shows a fish below the boat
seabed
Describe and explain how the reflected sound wave received by the boat from the fish differs from the reflected sound wave received from the seabed
A fisherman uses high frequency sound waves to locate fish in the sea. Fig. 8.1 shows the sound waves emitted from the boat
seabed
Describe the magnetic field around the charging plate in terms of its magnitude and direction
Explain why there is a current in the secondary coil shown in Fig. 9.2
Suggest why the transformer made from the charging plate and mobile phone is not \(100\%\) efficient
A mobile phone is placed on the charging plate as shown in Fig. 9.2. The coil in the mobile phone is part of a separate circuit that charges the battery
The coil in the charging plate and the coil in the mobile phone act like a transformer
Calculate the time taken to fully recharge a completely uncharged battery
Calculate the charge passing through the battery in 60 s

The mobile phone battery can be recharged using this charging plate and stores \(4.5 \times 10^{4} \text{J}\) of energy when fully recharged. The current in the secondary coil is \(0.63 \text{A}\) when the output voltage is \(12 \text{V}\)
Fig. 9.1 shows a wireless charging plate used to charge the battery in a mobile phone (cell phone). The coil of wire is part of an electric circuit
The charging plate is connected to an a.c. power supply. The power supply is turned on
Explain how an atom of carbon-14 ( \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C})\) differs from an atom of carbon-12 ( \(^{12}_{6}\mathrm {C}).\)
When an organism dies no new carbon is absorbed. The amount of carbon-12 in the dead organism remains fixed
Describe how the amount of carbon-14 in the dead organism decreases with time
A sample of wood contains carbon-14 to carbon-12 atoms in the ratio \(1:4 \times 10^{12}\)
Calculate how many years ago the tree died
.........  years ago
All living organisms contain both carbon-12 atoms and carbon-14 atoms. The ratio of carbon-14 to carbon-12 is \(1:1 \times 10^{12}\)
Carbon-14 has a half-life of 5700 years
Other radioactive isotopes have different half-lives
Suggest a use of a radioactive isotope with a half-life of one hour
Explain why a short half-life is suitable for this use
use
explanation
Carbon-14 ( \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C})\) is a radioactive isotope of carbon. Carbon-12 ( \(^{12}_{6}\mathrm {C})\) is not radioactive
State the name of one planet that has an orbit further away from the Sun than Venus
State the name of one planet that has an orbit closer to the Sun than Venus
Venus has an average radius of orbit of \(1.1 \times 10^{11} \text{m}\) and an orbital period of 220 Earth days. Calculate the average orbital speed of Venus. Give your answer in \(\text{m/s}\)
average orbital speed =   .........  m/s
State the relationship between the orbital speeds of the planets and their distances from the Sun
Comets are balls of ice and dust. Some comets orbit the Sun
State how the speed of a comet changes as it orbits the Sun
Explain your answer using ideas about the conservation of energy
You may include a labelled diagram in your answer
